p: Copper can prevent oxidative DNA damage and decrease inflammatory markers [ 37], as it is a part of antioxidant enzymes such as Zn-Cu-superoxide dismutase and ceruloplasmin [ 117]. Its deficiency is connected with an increased rate of infections [ 118], which may be related to its role in T-cell proliferation and Natural Killer (NK) activity [ 113]. On the other hand, macrophages can attack pathogens with high copper and as a result the concentration of copper may be found increased in lung infection [ 119]. However, no direct connection to COVID-19 has been identified to date.
